item.title: Kerry and Russian Counterpart Meet on Ukraine Crisis
item.description: As Secretary of State John Kerry began his meeting here with his Russian counterpart on Sunday to seek a political solution to the standoff over Ukraine, the federalization of the country was likely to be at the core of the discussion.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry with Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov of Russia before their meeting in Paris on Sunday.

item.title: North Korea Promises ‘New Form’ of Nuclear Test
item.description: The North did not elaborate, but Western analysts have long suspected that it is trying to make nuclear devices that could be delivered by intercontinental ballistic missiles.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Clock Ticks as Search for Missing Plane Intensifies in New Zone
item.description: Nine planes and eight ships scoured the latest search area, roughly the size of Poland, and more ships are on their way.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE and MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Large Crowds Fill Taipei Streets in Protest Over China Trade Bill
item.description: A pact that would drop barriers to trade in services with China has spurred concern in Taiwan, where student-led demonstrators continue to occupy the legislature.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Protesters attending a rally in Taipei to support students who have occupied the legislature for nearly two weeks.

item.title: Thai Protesters Rally, Reviving Drive Against Leaders
item.description: After a lull, critics of Thailand’s prime minister marched in Bangkok, seeking to force her out.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Cuba Moves to Attract More Foreign Investment
item.description: Cuban lawmakers on Saturday replaced a 1995 foreign investment law that has lured less overseas capital than the island’s Communist leaders had hoped.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Few Safe Places for Central African Republic’s Muslims
item.description: About 4,000 are trapped in one of the largest Muslim communities, afraid to leave lest they be harassed by Christian militia fighters.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: Same-Sex Couples Marry Under New Law
item.description: Some gay couples in Britain waited decades for the right to get married. When the opportunity came, it took just a few minutes to make history.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Tanya Ward, right, and Nikki Pettit, among the first gay couples to legally marry in Brighton, were showered on Saturday.

item.title: Leo Bretholz, 93, Dies; Escaped Train to Auschwitz
item.description: Mr. Bretholz testified in Congress in 2011, asking that Holocaust survivors be allowed to sue the French railway S.N.C.F. for its role in Nazi deportations to death camps.
item.category: S.N.C.F. (Societe Nationale des Chemins de fer Francais)
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By PAUL VITELLO
item.media:description: Leo Bretholz testified in Congress in 2011, asking that Holocaust survivors be allowed to sue a French railway for its role in death-camp deportations.

item.title: Credibility of Afghan Vote in Doubt as Observers Flee Violence
item.description: Many international election monitors curtailed their activities or made plans to evacuate their foreign employees, potentially raising serious questions about the election’s validity.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Afghan security forces blocked a street leading to election commission offices attacked Saturday.

item.title: As Diplomacy Steps Up, Ukraine Candidates Narrow
item.description: Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov of Russia, who will meet with Secretary of State John Kerry on Sunday, said the two sides were narrowing their differences.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR and ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Remaking a Life, After Years in an Israeli Prison
item.description: Demonized as terrorists by Israelis and lionized as freedom fighters by Palestinians, prisoners like Muqdad Salah have become a flash point in the troubled peace talks.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Muqdad Salah, who served time for killing an Israeli man, and Kefaya Abu Omar in Nablus in November for their wedding.

item.title: Hardy Divers in Korea Strait, ‘Sea Women’ Are Dwindling
item.description: For ages, the sea women of Jeju, off the southern coast of South Korea, have braved treacherous waters for their harvest.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Ukraine’s Hopes Riding on a Chocolatier
item.description: After a leading contender dropped out of Ukraine’s presidential race, the nation’s hopes and those of its Western supporters are now with the billionaire Petro Olekseyevich Poroshenko.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Petro Olekseyevich Poroshenko, left, became a strong advocate of integration with Europe after Russia moved to ban imports of his chocolate.

item.title: Opinion: Is the Lime an Endangered Species?
item.description: Mexican criminals are making a shortage worse.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID KARP

item.title: In Hunt for Lost Jet, New Sightings of Debris Are Promising but Inconclusive
item.description: Officials involved in the search, mindful of the amount of detritus adrift in the world’s oceans, cautioned that the sightings are inconclusive so far.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE
item.media:description: Ground crewmen in front of a Royal Malaysian Air Force C-130 Hercules shortly after it landed at the air base in Perth, Australia.

item.title: Amid Egypt’s Sweeping Crackdown, North Sinai Residents in Crossfire
item.description: Wreckage from assaults speaks to a crackdown so sweeping that even ardent supporters of the military say it risks spreading sympathy for the militants who are targeted.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MAYY EL SHEIKH and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: A crater from a car bomb scarred the road in November between Rafah and Arish in North Sinai, where Egypt’s military-led government is battling militants.

item.title: U. S. and Russia Step Up Diplomacy on Ukraine
item.description: Russian Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov, who will meet with Secretary of State John Kerry on Sunday, said the two sides were narrowing their differences.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Vitali Klitschko addressed Ukrainian supporters in London, following a meeting with British Prime Minister David Cameron on Wednesday.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Putin’s Reckless Gamble
item.description: Russia has stirred up passions that are hard to control. Has Putin decided he needs a breather?
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN SESTANOVICH

item.title: The Mines Have Shut Down. The Miners Haven’t.
item.description: Industrial coal mines of Lower Silesia, Poland, closed in the late 1990s, but the mining has continued in a more secret and dangerous form.
item.dc:creator: By DANNY HAKIM
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: The slag heap of the former Thorez coal mine in Walbrzych, Poland. Big industrial mines in the region closed down in the 1990s.

item.title: Taliban Attack Election Panel Headquarters Before Afghan Voting
item.description: The attack by the Taliban, who have vowed to violently derail the coming election for a new president, was the third in Kabul just this week.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Family Seeks Independent Autopsy of Activist Who Died in Detention
item.description: Two weeks after her death in custody, the government has yet to release Cao Shunli’s medical records to her family, and a lawyer describes “harassment” to drop the case.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: India Ink: In India, Some Misgivings About Abstention in U.N.’s Sri Lanka Vote
item.description: The Indian finance minister said he felt that India should have supported the resolution calling for an investigation of allegations of serious violations of human rights during Sri Lanka’s civil war, and a politician in Tamil Nadu accused the central government of abandoning ethnic Tamils.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Obama Ends Overseas Trip With Award for Saudi
item.description: The brief private ceremony came a day after the president chose not to raise the issue of human rights during a two-hour discussion with King Abdullah.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: President Obama presented Dr. Maha Al-Muneef with an International Women of Courage award during a private ceremony at the Ritz-Carlton on Saturday.

item.title: Putin Calls Obama to Discuss Ukraine, White House Says
item.description: In a phone call initiated by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, President Obama told Mr. Putin that the United States would like to see Russia pull back its troops from Crimea and not take any further steps into Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER, MICHAEL D. SHEAR and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Alexei Nikolsky/RIA Novosti Kremlin, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia called President Obama on Friday.
